title: Evolution of EU macro-regional strategies: present practice and future prospects, especially in the Mediterranean: REPORT the evolution of EU macro-regional strategies: present practice and future prospects, especially in the Mediterranean
background: Existing EU macro-regional strategies (Baltic, Danube), post-Arab Spring Mediterranean geopolitical shifts, and cross-border cooperation frameworks (Barcelona Process, MED/ENPI programs) inform discussions. The Parliament will discuss adapting macro-regional approaches to the Mediterranean, including sub-regional initiatives like the Adriatic-Ionian, to address shared challenges and enhance EU cohesion policy effectiveness.

stances.stance:
GREEN_EFA entirely approves the issue’s emphasis on youth mobility and educational exchanges, which perfectly aligns with their longstanding commitment to fostering cross-cultural understanding and combating brain drain through programs like a "Euro-Mediterranean Erasmus."  

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the call to simplify visa procedures for students and researchers, recognizing this as essential to strengthening academic networks and fulfilling the Mediterranean’s potential as a cohesive educational space.  

GREEN_EFA entirely approves the integration of Mediterranean youth initiatives, particularly the proposed synergies with the Mediterranean Office for Youth, as this directly advances their priority of empowering young voices in post-Arab Spring democratic transitions.  

GREEN_EFA perfectly supports the issue’s demand for automatic visa grants for participants in EU educational programs, viewing this as critical to achieving the environmental and cultural cooperation goals outlined in the Union for the Mediterranean framework.  

GREEN_EFA entirely approves leveraging Tempus and Erasmus Mundus funding to enhance teaching quality, aligning with their manifesto commitment to education as a tool for sustainable development and regional stability.

SD absolutely supports the issue’s emphasis on multilevel governance, aligning perfectly with SD’s commitment to empowering local authorities, civil society, and academic institutions in shaping macro-regional strategies, as underscored by Ţicău’s call for participatory frameworks mirroring the Danube model.  
SD perfectly aligns with the issue’s demand for binding resource allocation to macro-regional priorities, reflecting Smolková’s advocacy for systemic cohesion through supra-national Structural Fund coordination to eliminate development disparities.  
SD absolutely supports the integration of Mediterranean-specific environmental and infrastructural measures, resonating with Stavrakakis’s emphasis on combating drought, maritime pollution, and insularity via targeted energy and transport investments under Article 174 TFEU.  
SD applauds the issue’s vision for Euro-Mediterranean educational mobility programs, which directly advance SD’s manifesto goals of countering brain drain and fostering intercultural solidarity through Erasmus-style exchanges.  
SD underscores the issue’s geopolitical coherence in addressing post-Arab Spring challenges, perfectly aligning with SD’s principles of poverty reduction, fair trade, and democratic governance as pillars for Mediterranean stability.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the importance of developing macro-regional strategies to address shared challenges and foster sustainable growth, particularly in the Mediterranean and Adriatic-Ionian regions, building on existing frameworks like the Baltic Sea and Danube strategies. It emphasized the need for long-term EU funding, including cohesion and structural funds, to support cross-border cooperation, technical assistance, and projects with third countries, while advocating for "seed money" to initiate strategies. The resolution highlighted the Mediterranean’s geopolitical, cultural, and environmental coherence, spanning nearly 4,000 km, and stressed the potential of a macro-regional approach to enhance energy networks, maritime transport, environmental protection (e.g., combating pollution and overfishing), cultural heritage, and youth mobility. It called for leveraging existing programs like MED and ENPI, integrating the Union for the Mediterranean (UFM) and Adriatic-Ionian Initiative (AII), and addressing post-Arab Spring challenges through poverty reduction, fair trade, and democratic governance. Specific priorities included promoting south-south trade, reducing tariffs, and creating regional markets, alongside educational initiatives like a "Euro-Mediterranean Erasmus" and "Leonardo da Vinci" program to combat brain drain and strengthen cultural and academic exchanges. The resolution also underscored the role of islands under Article 174 TFEU, advocating for measures to mitigate their structural disadvantages in transport and energy. It urged synergies between EU policies, civil society engagement, and compliance with human rights principles, while highlighting the Adriatic-Ionian macro-region’s role in EU enlargement and reconciliation in the Western Balkans.

title: Eligibility of housing interventions in favour of marginalised communities: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation (EC) No .../2009 of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1080/2006 on the European Regional Development Fund as regards the eligibility of housing interventions in favour of marginalised communities
background: Persistent inadequate housing conditions among marginalized communities, particularly Roma populations in EU-12 rural areas, and disparities in ERDF eligibility criteria limiting interventions to urban regions prompted calls for regulatory alignment. The Parliament will discuss expanding ERDF-funded housing initiatives to all EU states, including rural areas, to address social exclusion through structural fund accessibility.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the expansion of ERDF eligibility to all Member States as completely challengeing with national sovereignty over immigration and housing policy.  
EFD opposes housing interventions that disregard British public opposition to EU-driven population growth, citing unresolved tensions from uncontrolled migration.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of local democratic control by enabling non-statutory bodies like the South-West Leaders’ Council to override community planning objections.  
EFD condemns the issue’s alignment with policies facilitating mass immigration, directly contradicting their principle of strict visa/permit-based population management.  
This framework completely challenges with EFD’s demand for national autonomy in addressing housing needs without EU-imposed demographic pressures.

GREEN_EFA totally upholds the expanded ERDF eligibility for housing interventions as a landmark achievement in combating social exclusion, perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to dignified living conditions for Roma and all marginalized communities.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s focus on energy poverty reduction and urban regeneration, recognizing its strategic synergy with the 2010 European Year Against Poverty and their climate justice priorities.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes the critical need for vigilance in fund allocation to prevent gentrification, proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms to ensure renovations prioritize community retention over speculative gains.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the mandate for post-2013 evaluations, urging explicit metrics on resident displacement rates and access to education/health services to solidify long-term social inclusion outcomes.  
GREEN_EFA reinforces the imperative for binding transparency criteria in future regulations to guarantee that vulnerable populations directly benefit from housing investments without bureaucratic barriers.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its approval of the amended Commission proposal (COM(2009)0382) concerning measures under Article 251(2) and Article 162 of the EC Treaty, emphasizing the need to align regional development policies with EU objectives. It mandated the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial revisions or replacements were planned, ensuring legislative oversight. The resolution further directed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council and the Commission, reinforcing procedural continuity and institutional cooperation in implementing the amended framework.

title: Contribution of EU regional policy towards fighting the financial and economic crisis, with a special reference to Objective 2: REPORT on the contribution of EU regional policy towards fighting the financial and economic crisis, with a special reference to Objective 2
background: The 2007-2013 EU Structural and Cohesion Funds, including Objective 2 targeting regional competitiveness, were deployed amid the 2008-2010 financial crisis under the European Economic Recovery Plan. The Parliament will discuss these policies’ role in mitigating economic disparities and crisis impacts through regional investments.

stances.stance:
EPP absolutely advocates the issue's emphasis on maintaining Objective 2 funding as critical for regional innovation ecosystems, perfectly aligning with EPP's commitment to fostering SME growth through targeted structural investments.  
EPP perfectly aligns with the call to simplify Structural Fund procedures, recognizing this as essential for accelerating crisis-response measures while maintaining strict cohesion policy priorities.  
EPP absolutely advocates integrating labor market strategies with cohesion programming, mirroring EPP's longstanding advocacy for skills-to-jobs alignment in all recovery frameworks.  
EPP unequivocally supports the issue’s rejection of post-2013 cohesion budget cuts, emphasizing that territorial cohesion remains indispensable for achieving Europe 2020 competitiveness targets.  
EPP perfectly aligns with leveraging EU funds to reduce regional disparities, particularly through smart specialization strategies that amplify local entrepreneurial potential as demonstrated in Mannheim and Irish case studies.

SD totally upholds the issue’s prioritization of cohesion policy as a crisis-response tool, perfectly aligning with SD’s commitment to combat regional economic fragmentation through targeted EU investments.  
SD perfectly aligns with the emphasis on Objective 2 regions’ multiplier effects, emphasizing Lower Austria’s proven model where EU funds generated triple-value local growth as foundational to SD’s regional equity agenda.  
SD unequivocally supports maintaining structural fund allocations at pre-2013 levels, recognizing their irreplaceable role in sustaining labor markets and SME resilience during systemic shocks.  
SD champions the issue’s demand for implementation flexibility, asserting this aligns with SD’s principle of adaptive regional governance to maximize crisis-era fund effectiveness.  
SD applauds the integration of climate action into cohesion programming as fully consistent with SD’s green transition priorities for EU-funded regional development.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns and recommendations regarding the EU’s cohesion policy and its role in addressing economic recovery, social disparities, and labor market challenges. It emphasized the need to align cohesion funding with the Europe 2020 strategy to promote smart, sustainable, and inclusive growth, particularly through investments in innovation, SMEs, green technologies, and digital infrastructure. The resolution highlighted the importance of maintaining adequate funding levels for structural funds (ERDF, ESF, Cohesion Fund), referencing the €336 billion allocated for 2007-2013, and called for streamlined implementation to address delays exacerbated by the financial crisis. It urged stronger focus on combating unemployment, especially youth and long-term unemployment, by aligning skills development with labor market needs, as outlined in the New Skills for New Jobs initiative. The Parliament stressed the need to reduce regional disparities, enhance territorial cooperation, and integrate climate action into cohesion programs. It also advocated for improved governance, transparency, and partnership with local authorities to ensure effective use of funds, while criticizing proposed budget cuts to cohesion policy post-2013 as counterproductive to recovery efforts.

title: Cohesion Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the Cohesion Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1084/2006
background: The Cohesion Fund, established under 2006 regulations, faced reforms to align with post-2013 EU priorities amid economic crises, regional disparities, and demands for strategic investment in growth, sustainability, and social inclusion. The Parliament will discuss updating the Fund’s governance, funding allocation mechanisms, and integration with broader EU economic and territorial cohesion objectives.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the Cohesion Fund's current structure for failing to address systemic inefficiencies and misallocation of resources, as evidenced by stagnant unemployment rates in Southern Italy despite previous funding.  
EFD opposes the prioritization of specific demographic groups in funding allocation, arguing this creates unequal treatment among EU citizens and diverts resources from broader economic needs.  
EFD fundamentally disapproves with the issue's reliance on EU-level financial mechanisms, citing Italy's disproportionate net contributions and lack of tangible benefits for national economies.  
EFD highlights the proposal's failure to ensure transparent and accountable use of funds, referencing documented cases of corruption in member states like Bulgaria.  
EFD criticizes the diversion of cohesion resources to large-scale infrastructure projects, which undermines the principle of reducing regional disparities through localized investments.

SD fully promotes the Cohesion Fund's strategic alignment with Europe 2020 goals, particularly its reinforced focus on youth employment and poverty reduction through mandatory ESF allocations, which perfectly advances SD's social equity priorities.  
SD highlights the critical enhancement of regional partnership principles, urging strengthened implementation frameworks to ensure local authorities' meaningful participation in program design as voiced by stakeholders.  
SD applauds the modernization of investment priorities to include clean energy and digital infrastructure, reflecting their manifesto commitment to sustainable territorial cohesion and climate action.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of maintaining elevated co-financing rates for outermost regions, proposing further simplification of administrative procedures to accelerate fund absorption while fully supporting the regulation's core objectives.  
SD underscores the importance of monitoring macroeconomic conditionality's social impacts, advocating for robust safeguards to prevent double penalization of vulnerable regions during austerity measures.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a Commission proposal (COM(2011)0612) concerning measures under Article 177 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, aimed at fostering economic, social, and territorial cohesion. It endorsed the Committee on Regional Development’s report and integrated opinions from multiple committees, including Budgets, Environment, Industry, and Transport, reflecting cross-sectoral priorities. The resolution emphasized adopting Parliament’s first-reading stance while urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments or alternative texts. It further instructed the President to formally transmit Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with EU legislative procedures and reinforcing interinstitutional accountability.

title: Common provisions on European funds: REPORT on the amended proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council laying down common provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund, the Cohesion Fund, the European Agricultural Fund for Rural Development and the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund covered by the Common Strategic Framework and laying down general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund and repealing Council Regulation (EC) No 1083/2006
background: The European Commission proposed amendments to regulations governing EU structural and investment funds (2011-2013), seeking to harmonize management under a Common Strategic Framework and repeal the 2006 framework. The Parliament will discuss the legislative framework for cohesion policy and fund provisions to align with EU strategic priorities for 2014-2020.

stances.stance:
ALDE strongly upholds the compromise maintaining the 23.1% ESF allocation, aligning with their commitment to balanced regional development and SME protection as economic growth drivers.  
ALDE totally upholds macroeconomic conditionality mechanisms tied to employment and GDP metrics, recognizing their alignment with fiscal responsibility principles in the Group's agenda.  
ALDE proposes enhancing Danube Strategy implementation through dedicated territorial cooperation instruments and clearer funding pathways to address regional disparities in line with Europe 2020 goals.  
ALDE approves performance reserve allocations and advance payment structures as tools to optimize cohesion policy effectiveness while safeguarding budgetary discipline.  
ALDE urges reinforced SME financing mechanisms through restored EIB funding thresholds, emphasizing their critical role in overcoming economic crises.

GUE/NGL rejects the macroeconomic conditionality clauses as fundamentally incompatible with solidarity principles, maintaining that austerity-linked fund suspensions punish vulnerable populations.  
GUE/NGL opposes the prioritization of private infrastructure investments and PPPs, which redirect public funds toward corporate interests rather than social housing or healthcare needs.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue’s failure to mandate poverty eradication programs, noting its shift toward employability metrics over concrete anti-homelessness measures.  
GUE/NGL denounces the undemocratic exclusion of amendments to remove macroeconomic sanctions, calling this procedural manipulation antithetical to parliamentary sovereignty.  
GUE/NGL fundamentally doubts with the cohesion policy’s alignment with Europe 2020 strategies, which accelerate privatization and deepen regional disparities through profit-driven projects.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding the Commission’s legislative proposals (COM(2011)0615 and subsequent amendments in 2012–2013) on regional development, emphasizing compliance with subsidiarity principles following a reasoned objection from the Italian Senate. It integrated opinions from multiple EU bodies, including the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2012, December 2012, May 2013), the Committee of the Regions (May 2012), and the Court of Auditors (December 2011), alongside input from parliamentary committees covering areas such as employment, environment, transport, and gender equality. The Parliament formally adopted its first-reading position (A7-0274/2013), urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments are made and instructing its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring alignment with Treaty obligations (Articles 177 and 294 TFEU) and procedural rules (Rule 55).

title: European Regional Development Fund and the 'European territorial cooperation' goal: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on specific provisions for the support from the European Regional Development Fund to the European territorial cooperation goal
background: The European Regional Development Fund’s role in advancing cross-border cooperation under the EU’s cohesion policy necessitated regulatory updates to align with strategic priorities and address implementation challenges. The Parliament will discuss specific provisions for ERDF support to the European territorial cooperation objective.

stances.stance:
ALDE entirely accepts the issue’s integration of macroeconomic conditionality, perfectly aligning with their commitment to fiscal stability and structural reform enforcement across EU member states.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the prioritization of small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) as engines of economic recovery, emphasizing the critical need to safeguard voluntary funding mechanisms that empower national initiatives.  
ALDE strongly agrees the Danube Strategy’s operationalization through territorial cooperation programs, recognizing its potential to address regional disparities and accelerate cross-border infrastructure development.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s balanced fund allocation framework, which protects regional development priorities while maintaining coherence with broader EU employment and poverty-reduction goals.  
ALDE commends the emphasis on interinstitutional transparency and procedural rigor, ensuring that legislative amendments remain aligned with the original proposal’s focus on territorial cohesion.

ECR partly advocates the issue’s focus on interinstitutional collaboration but requests revisions to Article 294 procedural frameworks to explicitly exclude macroeconomic conditionality penalties for cohesion fund recipients.  
ECR highlights contradictions with fiscal autonomy principles by opposing the issue’s integration of macroeconomic sanctions, which risk exacerbating regional disparities contrary to solidarity commitments.  
ECR proposes amending fund allocation clauses to mandate stricter national auditing mechanisms, referencing the European Court of Auditors’ recurrent findings on misdirected SME investments.  
ECR urges incorporating binding results-oriented benchmarks for West Wales and the Valleys’ convergence funding to rectify persistent poverty metrics despite prior EU allocations.  
ECR demands enhanced transparency requirements under the partnership principle, including real-time public disclosure of member state implementation frameworks to prevent infrastructural fund diversion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, adopting its first reading stance based on the Committee on Regional Development’s report and incorporating opinions from the Committees on Budgets, Budgetary Control, and Transport and Tourism (A7-0280/2013). It emphasized the need for the European Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the original 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0611) are planned, ensuring legislative coherence and transparency. The resolution instructed the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing interinstitutional collaboration and adherence to procedural frameworks under Article 294 of the Treaty. The text integrated prior consultations with the Committee of the Regions (July 2012) and the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2012), aligning regional and economic stakeholder perspectives with EU policy objectives.

title: European Regional Development Fund and the 'investment for growth and jobs' goal: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on specific provisions concerning the European Regional Development Fund and the Investment for growth and jobs goal and repealing Regulation (EC) No 1080/2006
background: The European Union's cohesion policy, established to reduce economic and social disparities among regions, faced evolving challenges post-2008 financial crisis, including youth unemployment and climate targets. Revisions to structural funds aimed to align with Europe 2020 growth strategies. The Parliament will discuss ERDF reforms targeting investment efficiency, thematic priorities, and regulatory simplification.

stances.stance:
ALDE entirely advocates the compromise maintaining the European Social Fund share at 23.1%, perfectly aligning with their commitment to preserving Regional Development Fund allocations critical for SME competitiveness and job creation.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s macroeconomic conditionality framework, recognizing its necessity to enforce fiscal discipline while safeguarding funding adjustments tied to employment and poverty metrics.  
ALDE strongly accepts the performance reserve mechanism and advance payment structures, affirming their role in ensuring accountability and measurable progress toward the Europe 2020 strategy’s goals.  
ALDE endorses the Danube Strategy’s integration into territorial cooperation instruments, emphasizing its potential to address regional disparities through targeted cross-border investments in infrastructure and innovation.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s focus on streamlining administrative procedures for SMEs, viewing it as essential to unlocking entrepreneurial potential and driving post-crisis economic recovery.

GUE/NGL rejects the undemocratic exclusion of amendments targeting macroeconomic sanctions, denouncing this as a breach of parliamentary autonomy.  
GUE/NGL condemns the prioritization of private infrastructure and airport expansions over social needs like housing and healthcare, reinforcing capitalist exploitation.  
GUE/NGL highlights the issue’s failure to combat poverty meaningfully, criticizing the ESF’s shift toward “employability” over direct social inclusion measures.  
GUE/NGL opposes reduced funding and restrictive criteria that deepen disparities between stronger and fragile economies, perpetuating dependency.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position at first reading on the Commission’s proposal COM(2011)0614, grounded in the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and informed by opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. It emphasized the need for the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are planned, ensuring parliamentary oversight. The resolution also mandated the Parliament’s President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to facilitate further legislative steps, underscoring procedural transparency and inter-institutional collaboration.

title: European Union Solidarity Fund: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EC) No 2012/2002 establishing the European Union Solidarity Fund
background: The EU Solidarity Fund, established in 2002 to address major natural disasters, faced operational challenges including delayed disbursements, complex eligibility criteria, and unsuccessful reform attempts in 2005. The Parliament will discuss amending the fund’s regulation to improve response mechanisms and accessibility for member states and regions affected by catastrophic events.

stances.stance:
EFD firmly conflicts the issue's approach as it fails to address EU environmental directives that restrict flood prevention measures like dredging, directly conflicting with EFD's anti-regulatory principles.  
EFD rejects the reliance on EU Solidarity Funding mechanisms, citing the UK's disproportionate financial contributions to the EU as evidence of systemic imbalance in crisis response frameworks.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of national sovereignty by maintaining EU control over disaster management, inconsistent with EFD's advocacy for local decision-making exemplified in the Somerset Levels flooding case.  
EFD highlights contradictions between the issue's institutional coordination goals and EU wildlife policies that prioritize habitat preservation over flood mitigation, exacerbating crises rather than resolving them.  
This completely conflicts with EFD's position that EU membership compounds governance failures, as demonstrated by the UK government's refusal to seek compensation for EU-caused infrastructure neglect.

GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the mandatory environmental prevention reporting requirements in the reformed Solidarity Fund, ensuring regions implement nature-based solutions like river restoration to qualify for aid.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s integration of ecological prevention standards as perfectly aligning with their manifesto commitment to climate-resilient infrastructure.  
GREEN_EFA endorses linking fund disbursements to proactive environmental safeguards, advancing their vision of harmonizing disaster response with long-term sustainability.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing Commission monitoring protocols to ensure uniform application of prevention criteria while fully backing the regulation’s core principles.  
This reform effectively advances GREEN_EFA’s priority of transforming post-disaster solidarity into systemic ecological risk reduction.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission proposal (COM(2013)0522), adopting its first-reading stance as outlined, which includes instructing the Commission to resubmit the matter to Parliament if substantial amendments or a replacement text are proposed. It emphasized procedural adherence by invoking Treaty provisions (Articles 294(2)-(3), 175, and 212(2) TFEU) and Rule 55 of its Rules of Procedure, while directing its President to formally communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The resolution incorporated inputs from the Committee on Regional Development’s report (A7-0078/2014) and the Committee on Budgets’ opinion, focusing on institutional coordination and ensuring parliamentary oversight over potential revisions to the proposal.

title: European Union Solidarity Fund, implementation and application: REPORT on the European Union Solidarity Fund, implementation and application
background: The European Union Solidarity Fund, established in 2002 to address major disasters, faced operational challenges including slow mobilization processes, bureaucratic complexities, and evolving disaster patterns. The European Commission proposed regulatory revisions to improve responsiveness. The Parliament will discuss reforms to enhance the fund's operational efficiency and disaster response mechanisms.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes the issue's call to streamline EUSF administrative procedures, aligning with members' emphasis on reducing delays and enhancing operational efficiency as highlighted by Sanchez-Schmid and Teixeira's practical experiences.  
EPP totally advocates expanding EUSF coverage to include "slowly unfolding" climate-related disasters, perfectly matching their commitment to addressing Mediterranean environmental challenges and urban resilience strategies discussed by Mazzoni and Jordan.  
EPP approves the critical linkage between EUSF and structural funds, reinforcing their longstanding priority of integrated territorial development as emphasized in Cozzolino's report and Zeller's urban focus.  
EPP proposes adjusting the regional GDP damage threshold calculation to better reflect actual recovery needs while maintaining rigorous accountability, addressing concerns raised in the issue about current rejection rates.  
EPP applauds the issue's focus on sustainable disaster prevention, strongly aligning with their manifesto goals on climate adaptation and cross-border energy projects advocated by Jordan and Gyürk.

EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on streamlining EUSF administrative procedures, proposing amendments to introduce upfront payments of 30% anticipated aid to accelerate crisis response, directly addressing delays criticized in Article 6.  
EFD advises revising the 1.5% regional GDP damage threshold to a dynamic model accounting for local economic vulnerabilities, aligning with concerns about high rejection rates while maintaining fiscal safeguards.  
EFD endorses expanding EUSF coverage to "slowly unfolding" climate-linked disasters but urges explicit recognition of regional energy autonomy, allowing fossil fuel-dependent areas transitional flexibility to avoid "energy poverty" as raised in cohesion policy debates.  
EFD supports integrating cascading socio-economic impacts into disaster definitions, suggesting Annex II amendments to include unemployment spikes and infrastructure collapse metrics post-catastrophe.  
EFD highlights the need to clarify EUSF’s complementary role with structural funds, proposing a joint taskforce to prevent overlaps in climate adaptation projects while maintaining the fund’s budgetary independence.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the critical role of the European Union Solidarity Fund (EUSF) as the primary mechanism for demonstrating EU solidarity by providing financial support to Member States and accession countries affected by major natural or man-made disasters. It emphasized the need to improve the Fund’s flexibility, speed, and operational efficiency, noting that 63% of past applications were submitted under the "regional disaster" category, with 66% rejected due to stringent criteria. The resolution highlighted excessive delays in mobilizing the EUSF, often exceeding a year, due to complex administrative procedures involving multiple EU institutions, and called for streamlined processes, including advances representing a fixed percentage of anticipated aid to accelerate assistance. It criticized the proposed 1.5% regional GDP damage threshold for eligibility as insufficient, arguing it would perpetuate high rejection rates and public frustration. The Parliament urged clearer definitions of disasters, expanded coverage for "slowly unfolding" events like droughts and Mediterranean disasters linked to climate change, and inclusion of cascading socio-economic impacts. It stressed the EUSF’s complementary role with other EU funds, such as structural funds, and advocated for sustainable disaster prevention. The resolution also underscored the need to maintain the EUSF outside the EU budget to ensure flexibility, while urging timely regulatory revisions before the 2014-2020 financial framework to enhance responsiveness and address evolving disaster risks.

title: European grouping of territorial cooperation: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1082/2006 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 5 July 2006 on a European grouping of territorial cooperation (EGTC) as regards the clarification, simplification and improvement of the establishment and implementation of such groupings
background: The 2006 EGTC Regulation established cross-border cooperation frameworks, but implementation challenges and evolving territorial cohesion priorities under the EU treaties prompted calls for procedural updates. The Parliament will discuss amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1082/2006 to clarify and streamline European territorial cooperation group formation and operational rules.

stances.stance:
SD totally accepts the issue's emphasis on territorial cohesion mechanisms that perfectly align with S&D's commitment to reducing regional disparities through enhanced cross-border cooperation.  
SD perfectly aligns with provisions enabling EGTCs to address energy transition and public health challenges, directly advancing SD's 2023 priorities for green infrastructure and social welfare integration.  
SD proposes strengthening Article 7 implementation guidelines to ensure strategic synergies between regional authorities and Commission directorates, addressing operational concerns raised during stakeholder consultations.  
SD applauds the issue's incorporation of Committee of Regions' input as fully consistent with S&D's governance model prioritizing multi-level decision-making and subsidiarity principles.  
SD emphasizes the critical need for swift operationalization of simplified funding procedures to maximize youth employment initiatives outlined in the European Social Fund provisions.

GUE_NGL partly approves the EGTC reform but demands removal of Article 7's macroeconomic conditionality, which weaponizes cohesion funds to enforce austerity—fully condemning with their anti-neoliberal governance principles.  

GUE_NGL requests revisions to prioritize social infrastructure in Article 4, opposing the current focus on private-sector projects like airports and energy monopolies that neglect housing, healthcare, and worker needs.  

GUE_NGL highlights the undemocratic bypassing of amendments on funding suspensions, overlooking critical safeguards against poverty escalation in crisis-hit regions as outlined in their 2022 cohesion manifesto.  

GUE_NGL criticizes the diluted ESF allocation (20% poverty target) as inconsistent with their demand for binding 25% minimums, urging stricter wording to prevent employability metrics from overriding direct social inclusion.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal concerning regional development and external action, adopting its first reading stance as outlined in the Committee on Regional Development’s report (A7-0309/2013). The resolution emphasized alignment with Treaty provisions, particularly Articles 175, 209(1), and 212(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union, which govern EU action in economic, social, and territorial cohesion, as well as development and external cooperation. It called on the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacements to the original 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0610/2) were planned, ensuring legislative transparency. The Parliament also instructed its President to formally communicate its adopted position to the Council, the Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural adherence under EU legislative frameworks. The resolution integrated opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (April 2012) and the Committee of the Regions (February 2012), reflecting stakeholder input while focusing on substantive policy coherence and institutional accountability.

title: General provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund as regards simplification of certain requirements and as regards certain provisions relating to financial management: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending regulation (EC) No 1083/2006 concerning general provisions on the European Regional Development Fund, the European Social Fund and the Cohesion Fund as regards simplification of certain requirements and as regards provisions relating to financial management
background: The European Union faced economic crisis impacts, administrative complexities in Structural Funds management, and delayed absorption of cohesion policy resources, prompting calls for streamlined procedures. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to simplify financial management and access requirements for the European Regional Development, Social, and Cohesion Funds.

stances.stance:

ALDE perfectly aligns with the advance payment mechanisms for liquidity support, recognizing their critical role in accelerating economic recovery for crisis-impacted Member States.  
ALDE strongly advocates the streamlined fund accessibility provisions, which effectively advance their priority of reducing bureaucratic barriers to EU-funded social and cohesion initiatives.  
ALDE highlights the issue’s alignment with lifelong learning strategies, reinforcing their advocacy for adaptable workforce training in a globalized economy.  
ALDE commends the focus on marginalized groups through ESF allocations, reflecting their longstanding dedication to inclusive social policy and equitable resource distribution.

GUE_NGL highlights the issue's inconsistency with their demand for maximal Structural Fund utilization to counteract rising poverty and precarious employment conditions  
GUE_NGL condemns the missed opportunity to operationalize Article 161's potential through binding mechanisms for social protection in cohesion spending  
GUE_NGL underscores the proposal's failure to address systemic underinvestment in public services critical to GUE/NGL's anti-austerity platform

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a proposed regulation concerning regional development, emphasizing alignment with Treaty provisions and interinstitutional procedures following the Lisbon Treaty’s entry into force. It adopted its first-reading stance, urging the Commission to re-engage Parliament if substantial amendments or replacement of the proposal (COM(2009)0384) were planned, ensuring legislative transparency and continuity.
